feed.title: Worship services - Trinity and Cores End URCs

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs
Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 18th December 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
10:14 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder) Call to worship God of creation, God of history: God is here with us. God of mystery, God of blessing: God is here with us. God in Jesus, God named Emmanuel: God is here with us.
HYMN Joy to the world, the Lord is come (R&S 135)
Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
Introduction: Nativity now – what part would you play?
CAROL The angel Gabriel (R&S 139)
Lighting the Advent candles As we light the last candle before Christmas Day, we give thanks for the role Mary and Joseph played in God’s unfolding plan and pray: God of all our lives, you call each of us to play a part in your story and purposes for the world. As we give thanks for the courage and the humility of Mary and Joseph, may shine your light into the lives of others. Draw us all to the Christmas stable, where hope is born and all are loved, in Jesus’ name. Amen.
Reading: Isaiah 7.10 – 16 GN read by John Hillson (from chair) 10 The LORD sent another message to Ahaz: 11 “Ask the LORD your God to give you a sign. It can be from deep in the world of the dead or from high up in heaven.”
12 Ahaz answered, “I will not ask for a sign. I refuse to put the LORD to the test.” 13 To that Isaiah replied, “Listen, now, descendants of King David. It's bad enough for you to wear out the patience of people—do you have to wear out God's patience too? 14 Well then, the Lord himself will give you a sign: a young woman who is pregnant will have a son and will name him ‘Immanuel.’ 15 By the time he is old enough to make his own decisions, people will be drinking milk and eating honey. 16 Even before that time comes, the lands of those two kings who terrify you will be deserted.
SONG Emmanuel, Emmanuel (MP 121) sung three times Emmanuel, Emmanuel, His name is called Emmanuel God with us, revealed in us – His name is called Emmanuel
Find Mary…find Joseph (carols R&S 144 – 181)
Matthew 1. 18 – 25 NIVUK read by Sue Thorne 18 This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about: his mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit. 19 Because Joseph her husband was faithful to the law, and yet did not want to expose her to public disgrace, he had in mind to divorce her quietly. 20 But after he had considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, ‘Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. 21 She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.’ 22 All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: 23 ‘The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel’ (which means ‘God with us’). 24 When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. 25 But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.
CAROL Joseph, son of David (Tune R&S 243 Noel nouvelet) 1. Joseph, son of David, son of Abraham; regally descended, son of tent and psalm; waited the day when, filled with joy and pride, he would marry Mary, she would be his bride.
2. Joseph, though a poor man, with no wealth or fame, yet possessed a treasure in his fam’ly name. He must pass on this honour to his son, in the line of David – then his job was done! 3. Yet, before the wedding, Mary was with child and there was no father; ev’ryone went wild! What could he do, to keep his name intact? Mary must be banished! Surely he must act! 4. Calmly, at God’s prompting, Joseph held his ground, risking, trusting, waiting; Mary still around. Somehow he knew, though how he could not tell, God would act through Jesus, all would then be well. 5. Showing such devotion, Joseph stood in line with ancestral women working God’s design: Rahab, and Tamar, Bathsheba and Ruth – each, when others faltered, stood for hope and truth. 6. Now the gift of Joseph – ancestry and name – graciously surrendered, nevermore the same; offered to Jesus, ’til God’s work is done, welcomes all the nations, seeks to make us one. © John Campbell (based on Matthew 1)
Short Talk
SONG Born in the night, Mary’s child (R&S 188) sung seated
Prayers for each other and the world
CAROL See! In yonder manger low (R&S 157)
Blessing
Music, notices and photos
#Church #Worship #Advent #AllAreWelcome #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Hope #Isaiah #FourCandles #ForkHandles #Matthew

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 11th December 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
07:35 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (Linda as duty elder)
08:32 - Introduction – Linda
09:50 - 13:40 - Carol: In the Bleak Mid-Winter (R&S 162)
13:46 - Story Telling – Julia What are you looking forward to most about Christmas Dinner Cousins Grandchildren Now think back to when you were a child? Presents Stocking Which do you like best - giving or receiving Why do we give presents? Enjoyment, showing our love for one another, reminding us of the first Christmas present wrapped in strips of cloth Jesus was the first and best Remembering our friends, family and God at Christmas We need to receive, unwrap, thank, enjoy, and share our presents and God's present of Jesus
17:47 - 19:00 - Reading: Luke 2. 4-12 (NIVUK) – Samuel 4 So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. 5 He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. 6 While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, 7 and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them. 8 And there were shepherds living out in the fields near by, keeping watch over their flocks at night. 9 An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. 10 But the angel said to them, ‘Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. 11 Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. 12 This will be a sign to you: you will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.’
19:14 - 23:17 - Carol - We Three Kings of Orient Are
23:33 - 24:37 - Reading: Matthew 2. 1-2, 9-12 (NIVUK) After Jesus was born in Bethlehem in Judea, during the time of King Herod, Magi from the east came to Jerusalem 2 and asked, ‘Where is the one who has been born king of the Jews? We saw his star when it rose and have come to worship him.’ 9 After they had heard the king, they went on their way, and the star they had seen when it rose went ahead of them until it stopped over the place where the child was. 10 When they saw the star, they were overjoyed. 11 On coming to the house, they saw the child with his mother Mary, and they bowed down and worshipped him. Then they opened their treasures and presented him with gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh. 12 And having been warned in a dream not to go back to Herod, they returned to their country by another route.
24:46 - Lighting of the Advent Candle – Samuel
26:18 - 29:30 - Carol - Good King Wenceslas (verses 1-3, 5)
29:37 - Introduction to Activities - Print wrapping paper) – Sarah - Christmas Stocking – Sarah - Story Teller – Linda - Edible Baby – Julia - Themed crossword for those sitting – Ellen - At home – Ellen
58:58 - 01:01:34 - Carol - Come and Join the Celebration (R&S 166)
01:01:40 - Prayers and Lord’s Prayer – Sarah
01:06:32 - 01:19:56 - Carol - Hark the Herald Angels Sing (R&S 159)
01:10:03 - 01:10:40 - Messy Grace – Linda
01:10:56 - Music, notices and photos
#Church #Worship #Advent #AllAreWelcome #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Hope #Isaiah #Paul #Romans

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 4th December 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
08:30 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder) #Ukraine
10:20 - Call to worship (based on Psalm 72. 18,19) Praise be to the Lord God, the God of Israel, the God of all people the God who alone does marvellous deeds. Praise be to God’s glorious name for ever; may the whole earth be filled with God’s glory. Seen in the Face of Jesus, Emmanuel, God with us for ever and ever. Amen.
11:18 - 15:51 - Hymn - O come o come Emmanuel (R&S 126 vs. 1 – 5) Four candles and the great Os
16:11 - Prayer of adoration and confession
18:09 - Introduction for all ages: ‘Speaking up, speaking out’ Have any of you joined a protest march? Would you ever join one? Cancel the debt? Having a phobia of crowds, feeling uncomfortable in them but admiring those who do protest What would you protest about? CND, Mahsa Amini, China, Extinction Rebellion, Insulate Britain Local protests What would go on your banner? Prayer as a kind of protest "It is better to light a candle than curse the darkness"
27:30 - Lighting of 2nd Advent candle Reader: As we light the second Advent candle, we remember the prophets of the past and the present, witnessing to the justice and peace God wants for this world. And we pray that we too may be ready to speak out against evil and wrong and show God’s love today All: Lord Jesus, light of the world, born to bring peace and love to a hurting world. Help us to follow your way and to know your peace this Christmastide. Amen.
32:35 - 35:398 - Hymn - Make way, make way (R&S 141)
36:10 - Introducing the first reading: ‘a world transformed’
37:01 - 38:40 - Reading: Isaiah 11.1-10 (NIVUK) read by Eljse Hatton
39:10 - 42:10 - Hymn - Hills of the north rejoice vs 5 (CP 337)
42:18 - 43:52 - Reading: Romans 15.4-13 (NIVUK) read by Tony Hatton
44:20 - Short Address What does hope mean in your lives? This is the season of hope and light Sharing 3 pictures of hope The great reading from Romans of hope overflowing Take that hope home with you Firstly from hundreds of years ago, a tiny middle eastern nation being surrounded and the invasion becoming a certainty Isaiah delivered a message of hope to Judah Secondly from a man who had endures much suffering in his life yet held on to the love of God and the hope of Christ Paul writing to the Christians in Rome against the evil empire Finally from Cambridge when studying economics A small christian group called the ecumenical fellowship group Meeting, discussing and planning social action, going to the local psychiatric hospital to sit with and talk to some of the patients
53:20 - 58:20 - Prayers for the church and the world
58:40 - 01:01:10 - Hymn - Hark the glad sound (R&S 137)
01:01:18 - Thanksgiving Prayer and Lord’s Prayer 01:04:17 - Distribution of bread and wine and Closing Prayer
01:11:02 - 01:13:54 - Hymn - Joy to the world (R&S 135ii)
01:13:55 - 01:14:26 - Blessing
01:14:51 - 01:18:44 - Music, notices and photos
#Church #Worship #Advent #AllAreWelcome #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Hope #Isaiah #Paul #Romans

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 27th November 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
11:15 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
13:46 - Call to worship - Psalm 122
15:04 - 21:54 - Hymn: O Come o come Emanuel R&S126
21:58 - Prayer of adoration and confession
25:05 - Lord’s Prayer
26:05 - Reading: Matthew 24 vv 36-44 Read by Kate Yates
27:10 - 30:37 - All age talk and intro Boys' Brigade camp & worrying about people being sick on the coach Phobias Working in care for so many years and being unable to deal with sick "Are we there yet?" Donkey, Shrek and Fiona in Shrek 2 The answer never comes until all of a sudden it does We are told in our readings to prepare as we don't know the time and the hour Penitential seasons before the two great festivals of Easter and Christmas Thinking more about getting ready for Christ Extending our prayer life The start of the lectionary aligns with Advent We have to prepare and be ready
30:51 - 34:02 - Hymn: Light of the World MP1086
34:10 - Lighting of the Advent Candle
37:05 - 38:18 - Reading: Isaiah 2 vv 1-5 read by Kate Yates
38:36 - 40:37 - Hymn: Come thou long expected Jesus R&S 138
40:42 - 52:33 - Address Matthew 23 vv34 - Truly I tell you this generation will not pass away until all these things have happened Reading v34, Matthew could not have thought of this generation only lasting 30-40 years after the crucifixion, but maybe before all of Jesus' had passed away Compare to v36 - "But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father" We know so little, constantly confounded by events Jesus says "about that day and hour no-one knows" Remembering days or hours about which I did not know - friends telling they have terminal cancer, meeting a future spouse, going to court to get justice, being asked to pray for a COVID sufferer The day or hour about which we do not know comes to us all in thousands of different ways We have no way of knowing whether it will be welcome or unwelcome Jesus says "Keep awake and be ready" but for what? We don't know but that is how life unfolds, it deepens the meaning of life. Everything matters and we should not want to miss a moment
52:50 - 55:19 - Hymn: Hark the glad sound the Saviour comes R&S 137
55:23 - Offering Prayer Prayers for the church and the world
59:42 - 01:04:46 - Hymn: Lo He comes with clouds descending R&S 656
01:04:47 - 01:05:08 - Blessing
01:05:34 - 01:09:00 - Organ voluntary, notices and photos
#Advent #Church #Jesus #Sing #Hymn #AdventCandle #Candle

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 20th November 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
13:17 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
15:13 - Call to worship
Strength through vulnerability, peace through pain: Jesus is the image of the unseen God. Courage through truth, light through darkness: Jesus is the image of the unseen God.
15:49 - Hymn - MP 465 Meekness and majesty
19:56 - Prayer of adoration and confession Lord’s Prayer
22:48- 26:59 - Introducing of today’s theme: ‘Christ the King’
27:31 - 28:51 - Reading: Jeremiah 23.1-6 (NIVUK) read by David Bishop 23 ‘Woe to the shepherds who are destroying and scattering the sheep of my pasture!’ declares the LORD. 2 Therefore this is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says to the shepherds who tend my people: ‘Because you have scattered my flock and driven them away and have not bestowed care on them, I will bestow punishment on you for the evil you have done,’ declares the LORD. 3 ‘I myself will gather the remnant of my flock out of all the countries where I have driven them and will bring them back to their pasture, where they will be fruitful and increase in number. 4 I will place shepherds over them who will tend them, and they will no longer be afraid or terrified, nor will any be missing,’ declares the LORD. 5 ‘The days are coming,’ declares the LORD, ‘when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch, a King who will reign wisely and do what is just and right in the land. 6 In his days Judah will be saved and Israel will live in safety. This is the name by which he will be called: The LORD Our Righteous Saviour.
29:40 - 33:12 - Hymn MP 1008 The Lord’s my shepherd (Stuart Townend)
33:18 - Activity: ‘A king chart’ Thinking about Kings What do you associate with the word King? Castles Privilege Wealth Heredity Fine Clothes Powerful Authority War History Which of these connect with Christ the King? Powerful, crown, heritage, authority, history That's not enough, let's add some words specific to Jesus Faithful, loving, shepherd, servant, compassionate, humble
48:10 - Pilate's sign above the cross - Jesus King of the Jews
49:28 - Reading Luke 23.33-43 (NIVUK) read by Val Bishop 33 When they came to the place called the Skull, they crucified him there, along with the criminals – one on his right, the other on his left. 34 Jesus said, ‘Father, forgive them, for they do not know what they are doing.’ [a] And they divided up his clothes by casting lots. 35 The people stood watching, and the rulers even sneered at him. They said, ‘He saved others; let him save himself if he is God’s Messiah, the Chosen One.’ 36 The soldiers also came up and mocked him. They offered him wine vinegar 37 and said, ‘If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself.’ 38 There was a written notice above him, which read: THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS. 39 One of the criminals who hung there hurled insults at him: ‘Aren’t you the Messiah? Save yourself and us!’ 40 But the other criminal rebuked him. ‘Don’t you fear God,’ he said, ‘since you are under the same sentence? 41 We are punished justly, for we are getting what our deeds deserve. But this man has done nothing wrong.’ 42 Then he said, ‘Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom.’ 43 Jesus answered him, ‘Truly I tell you, today you will be with me in paradise.’
51:04 - 53:05 - Short talk: Preparing for the King, praying for the kingdom One of the great prayers of the New Testament - "Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom" This is an incredible King we are thinking of In our system, the monarchy recognises its dependence on God, a King of love He is the King of Kings Next Sunday at the beginning of Advent we begin to prepare for the arrival of our King
53:06 - Craft Activity: Crown of love
01:03:50 - 01:08:00 - Hymn R&S 522 From heaven you came
01:08:34 - Offering Prayer Lord, show us where and how we can serve you, the king who serves and gives yourself for us. In our words and in our lives, we will worship you, The King of love, the Prince of Peace.
01:09:30 - Taize Song - Jesus remember me (sung three times) Jesus remember me, when you come into your kingdom…
01:11:11 - Prayers for the world with the response Jesus, King of love, remember them today.
01:15:39 - 01:19:01 - Hymn R&S 262 Crown him the Lord of life
01:19:02 - 01:19:37 - Blessing Let us hold fast to that which is good In the strength of Jesus we are powerful Let us never give in to evil. In the peace of Jesus we are forgiven Let follow his way of compassion In the love of Jesus we are encircled Blessed today and always Amen.
01:19:54 - 01:22:45 - Music and notices after the service
#StirUpSunday #Church #Worship #Jeremiah #Luke #Bible #Crowns #JuniorChurch #TheLordsMyShepherd #Shepherd #Lord #God #Jesus

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 13th November 2022 - Remembrance Sunday

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 13th November 2022 - Remembrance Sunday
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
10:43 - Welcome and notices (an elder)
Call to worship Lighting of Peace candle Minister: On this Remembrance Sunday, we affirm that God is with us now, source of true peace. All: Be present with us, Lord, bring life and hope. Minister: We remember the victory of Jesus Christ over death and hatred and his greeting ‘Peace be with you’: All: Be present with us, Lord, bring grace and peace. Minister: Christ’s light shines in our world and in our hearts and the world’s darkness will never overcome it: All: Be present with us, Lord: lead us by the light of your love and truth.
13:16 - 15:57 - Hymn MP 1201 Longing for light (vs 1,2 and 5)
15:58 - 18:11 - Prayer of adoration and confession
18:17 - 25:04 - Introduction for all ages: ‘peace begins here and now’ Today is the day we remember The different colours of poppies now available White for peace, red for suffering and sacrifice What other colours will be made available in the future as we recognise the impact of war Imagine a pebble, holding it in your hand Ripples in the water Turning hearts of stone to love
Lord, lead me from death to life, from falsehood to truth; lead me from despair to hope, from fear to trust; lead me from hate to love, from war to peace. Let peace fill our heart, our world, our universe. Amen.
25:22 - 26:50 - Reading: Micah 4: 1 – 5 read by Larry Ogbewe 4 In the last days the mountain of the LORD’s temple will be established as the highest of the mountains; it will be exalted above the hills, and peoples will stream to it. 2 Many nations will come and say, ‘Come, let us go up to the mountain of the LORD, to the temple of the God of Jacob. He will teach us his ways, so that we may walk in his paths.’ The law will go out from Zion, the word of the LORD from Jerusalem. 3 He will judge between many peoples and will settle disputes for strong nations far and wide. They will beat their swords into ploughshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation will not take up sword against nation, nor will they train for war any more. 4 Everyone will sit under their own vine and under their own fig-tree, and no one will make them afraid, for the LORD Almighty has spoken. 5 All the nations may walk in the name of their gods, but we will walk in the name of the LORD our God for ever and ever.
27:57 - 29:12 - Reading: Revelation 22. 1 – 5 read by Norma Garden Then the angel showed me the river of the water of life, as clear as crystal, flowing from the throne of God and of the Lamb 2 down the middle of the great street of the city. On each side of the river stood the tree of life, bearing twelve crops of fruit, yielding its fruit every month. And the leaves of the tree are for the healing of the nations. 3 No longer will there be any curse. The throne of God and of the Lamb will be in the city, and his servants will serve him. 4 They will see his face, and his name will be on their foreheads. 5 There will be no more night. They will not need the light of a lamp or the light of the sun, for the Lord God will give them light. And they will reign for ever and ever.
30:01 - Hymn R&S 477 - Let there be love shared among us
32:07 - Prayer before the Act of Remembrance
36:56 - Act of remembrance at 11 am They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old; age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. At the going down of the sun and in the morning, we will remember them. We will remember them.
The two minutes of silence Prayers
43:19 - 46:36 - Hymn - R&S 705 Our God, our help in ages past
46:42 - 01:00:36 - Short Address: ‘healing a broken world’
Minister: On this day when our nation remembers the sacrifices of the past and the conflicts and crises of the present, we offer our lives once more for God’s work of healing a broken world and bringing peace and justice to all: All: God of hope, we commit ourselves to your way of truth and compassion. As we work for peace – give us wisdom, as we strive for justice – give us courage, as we care for those in need – give us compassion. As we strive to protect the planet – give us hope Through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen.
01:00:52 - 01:04:20 - Hymn R&S 629 Make me a channel of your peace
01:04:24 - Thanksgiving Prayer and Lord’s Prayer
01:07:19 - Distribution of bread and wine
01:13:40 - Closing Prayer
01:14:37 - 01:17:50 - Hymn R&S 620 For the healing of the nations
01:17:52 - 01:18:30 - Blessing
01:18:58 - 01:22:14 - Music and notices after the service
#Remembrance #WeWillRemenberThem #NeverForget #Poppy #Poppies #Flanders #Church #Worship #Cenotaph

entry.title: Trinity URC Sunday 6th November 2022 led by Rebecca Hawes

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC Sunday 6th November 2022 led by Rebecca Hawes
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
13:51 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
15:47 - Call to worship
16:38 - 19:44 - Hymn: Alleluia, Sing to Jesus ( to tune MP315 ).
19:51 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
22:34 - 27:50 - Talk for all ages A wonderful catchphrase for the Christian faith A quiz - who said this? To infinity and beyond Nice to see you , to see you nice Here's one I made earlier Simples Ahana means family, family means no-one gets left behind I have a cunning plan Think happy thoughts We know those catchphrases because they are used by people and we learn about those people by their use If you had a catchphrase, would it tell us about you? The phrase that Job uses - I know that my redeemer lives He clings on to this through his trials and tribulations Peter says we should always have hope A challenge - how can we live our lives so that we point to the hope we have in Jesus
28:10 - 30:44 - Hymn Come on and Celebrate ( TP23 )
30:55 - Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities:
31:55 - Reading: Job 19:23-27a read by Samuel Evans
32:40 - Update on the work of Wycombe YFC Sharing the "Encounter" project in secondary schools A place young people can come to and put their gifts and talents to use Launched just under 12 months ago Real growth in young people offering to help A new worship band A safe space to encounter God Helping at Lighthouse Cressex supporting the lamplighters Mentoring and pastoral support in primary schools
44:16 - 46:15 - Reading: 2 Thessalonians 2:1-5 & 13-end read by Kitty Bird
46:133 - 50:01 - Hymn: Lord for the Years (R&S 603)
Sermon followed by time of quiet reflection
Hymn: How sweet the name of Jesus sounds (R&S 277)
Prayers for others and ourselves
Hymn: O Jesus I have Promised (R&S 509) new tune
Closing blessing
Organ voluntary and photos/notices
#WycombeYouthForChrist #WYFC #YFC #Job19 #thessalonians #church #god #worship #jesus #urc #unitedreformedchurch #AllAreWelcome

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC Sunday 30th October 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening Music on the Organ.
07:39 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
09:38 - Call to worship What does the Lord our God require of us? Is it not to act justly, love mercy and walk humbly with our God.
10:34 - 15:30 - Hymn - Let us build a house © Marty Haugen 1994 GIA Publications
15:32 - Opening Prayers with the response May the love of Christ unite us in wonder, love and praise.
Lord’s Prayer
19:02 - Introduction for all ages – out of the box! If you filled a box, what might be in it? Soap, flannels, a toy, toothbrush & paste, a hat and scarf Shoebox Collection: Daphne Stopforth updates us on the work of
22:07 - Link to Hope in Eastern Europe (including Ukraine) and collects any Christmas shoeboxes you have brought to church today
28:32 - 31:09 - Song from Ukraine (recording) Lord, oh the Great and Almighty, protect our beloved Ukraine, Bless her with freedom and light of your holy rays. With learning and knowledge enlighten us, your children small, In love pure and everlasting, let us, oh Lord, grow. We pray, oh Lord Almighty, protect our beloved Ukraine, Grant our people and country all your kindness and grace. Bless us with freedom, bless us with wisdom, Guide into a kind world, Bless us, oh Lord, with good fortune for ever and evermore.
31:39 - 33:15 - Reading: Isaiah 1.10 – 18 (NIVUK) read by Linda Curley
34:23 - 44:26 - Update on Commitment for Life given by Angus Massie. Our focus is on Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories.
45:40 - 47:56 - Hymn MP 376 - Jesus taught how to be a family
48:23 - 49:41 - Reading: Luke 19.1 – 10 (NIVUK) read by Julia Sparks
50:23 - 52:02 - Hymn R&S 92 - Amazing grace (vs 1 and 2 only, sung seated as a prayer)
52:08 - 01:01:52 - Short Talk Jesus is on his way to Jerusalem A city so important to people before and after through the centuries. He went to confront hypocrisy He knows this is part of God's plan to save the world He has important business to do - global salvation The little town of Jericho has to be passed through A little man up a tree catches his eye and despite the huge task ahead, Jesus pauses and gives him his attention No-one is beyond Jesus' attention
01:01:57 - Prayers for the church and the world with sung response Hymn R&S 401 - Through our lives
01:09:28 - 01:12:34 - Hymn - R&S 567 Thy hand, O God, has guided
01:12:36 - 01:13:05 - Blessing
01:13:28 - 01:17:33 - Organ voluntary and photos/notices

entry.title: Trinity URC Compassion Sunday Guest speaker 23rd Oct

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC Compassion Sunday Guest speaker 23rd Oct
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
07:34 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (elder)
09:35 - Call to worship: words from Psalm 24
10:34 - 13:11 Hymn: Jesus shall reign where’er the sun R&S 269
13:20 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
15:49 - 20:48 - Trinity's sponsored children
20:55 - 39:18 - My story – Miss Dilini Paul Our impact: More than 3,000 hours for children at the projects we support More than 1,000 nutritious meals More than 15 medical checkups 20 Letters sent, 9 letters received
39:54 - 42:58 - Worship song: Blessed assurance
Blessing as Junior Church go to their activities: Adults: May the Lord be with you Junior Church: And also with you All: Amen
Introduction to Bible readings
43:52 - 45:23 - Reading: Exodus 2 vv 5-10 read by Jeany Bien
45:37 - 49:18 - Hymn: King of Kings MP100
49:40 - 01:04:21 - Talk - Mr Vinoraj Thavarasa followed by time of quiet reflection Sponsored children, how we help Guatemala Pharoah's daughter stopping by the water's edge God putting compassion into her heart She was willing to put forward her love and resources to care for the child
01:06:07 - 01:10:07 - Hymn: Christ be our light MP1201
01:10:23 - Prayers for others and ourselves led by Rosemary
01:13:50 - 01:17:34 - Hymn: We’ve a story to tell to the nations MP744
01:17:35 - 01:17:53 - Closing blessing The Grace
01:18:11 - 01:22:30 - Organ voluntary, photos, and notices
#God #exodus #Compassion #Jesus #sponsorachild #mushroom #berries #berry #autumn #leaves

entry.title: Trinity URC morning worship 16th Oct led by church members

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC morning worship 16th Oct led by church members
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
12:55 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (elder)
13:50 - Kate to introduce David Reynold’s video 15:17 - 17:30 - David Reynold’s video
17:39 - Call to worship 2 Corinthians 3:18 And we, who with unveiled faces all reflect the Lord’s glory, are being transformed into his likeness with ever-increasing glory, which from the Lord, who is the Spirit.
18:05 - Hymn – R&S 489 Be thou my vision
21:52 - Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
24:00 - 28:18 - Short introduction to Compassion by Marian Drake followed by a video preparing us for next Sunday’s service for Compassion Sunday
28:35 - Hymn – R&S 522 From heaven you came (Servant King)
33:01 - Introduction to Bible readings We will now listen to our readings
Readings
33:16 - 36:50 - Psalm 139 read by John Hillson
36:58 - 38:27 - John 9:1-11 read by Lesley Bogart
38:46 - Hymn – R&S 549 One more step along the way I go
42:29 - Poem written and read by David Reynolds
43:55 - Hymn – R&S 518 Father I place into your hands
46:34 - 53:30 - Short Address – Made in God’s image Psalm 139 has inspired many From v13 the psalmist reflects on how he has been made for a purpose and calling We too are formed in the image of God - the image may be perfect but we are not. Yet all are precious in His sight The John 9 story is beautifully crafted looking at the perceived "fault" of the blind man Jesus could use the situation to manifest his glory The sign points to Jesus as the light of the world "Not unto us o Lord, not unto us but to Your name be the glory"
53:42 - Video – “Made in God’s Image”
59:47 - Offering prayer (no collection is taken up but prayer can acknowledge our gifts to God)
01:00:29 - Prayers for the world led by Kate Yates
01:05:34 - 01:10:30 - Hymn – R&S 117 How Great Thou Art
01:10:31 - 01:10:40 - Closing Blessing
01:11:08 - 01:14:32 - Organ voluntary, photos, notices
#God #godsimage #sightloss #torchtrust #psalm139 #john1v9 #john1 #2corinthians3

entry.title: Trinity URC morning worship 9th Oct led by Rev Bridget Powell

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Trinity URC morning worship 9th Oct led by Rev Bridget Powell
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
09:40 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
11:35 - Call to worship: Verses from Psalm 111
13:39 - Hymn: R&S 60 God who spoke in the beginning To tune Rhuddlan 344
16:08 - Opening Prayer and The Lord’s Prayer
19:50 - 30:05 - Introduction to the theme: Saying Thank You I have in mind a story from the Gospel Do you remember the story where Jesus met 10 lepers on the road They didn't come near but said to him - "Master, have pity on us" He told them to go to the priest and they would be cleansed There are 200,000 people suffering with leprosy in 2020 It can be cured now but there is still a lot of it around These 10 men did not have access to modern medicine, they would have gone to a colony, gradually lost the use of their extremities. However, they did as told, went to the priest and were seen as cured. Only one of them turned back to Jesus to thank him Do we always remember to say thank you? ACTS mnemonic for how to pray - Adoration, Confession, Thanksgiving, and Supplication What would you like to give thanks for today?
30:18 - Hymn - R&S 302 O breath of life come sweeping through us
33:28 - Introduction to the readings
35:04 - 38:44 - Readings: 2 Kings 5:1-15 NIVUK Naaman healed of leprosy
39:25 - 40:41 - Luke 17: 11-19 NIVUK Jesus heals ten men with leprosy
41:10 - Hymn: R&S 492 Dear Lord and Father of mankind
46:02 - 01:06:14 - Sermon: First impressions followed by time of quite reflection I wanted to start thinking about how we see things First impressions and the need to revisit them A mishmash of faces An optical illusion of the word Jesus The face of Jesus Have you ever met someone who you are not sure whether you wish to be friends with? You gradually spend more time with them and find out more before becoming friends How would you describe yourself in one word? Naaman and the slave girl Not just a physical healing but a spiritual one as well Our experiences form who we become Help us to see people as Jesus sees them
01:06:50 - Hymn - R&S 648 Jesu, Jesu, fill us with your love
01:09:28 - Prayers of Intercession Response: Gracious Lord, hear our prayers
01:15:22 - Hymn: R&S 200 The Kingdom of God is justice and joy
01:18:16 - 01:18:36 - Blessing
01:19:23 - 01:25:18 - Music and photographs after the service
#Worship #Naaman #Leprosy #Healing #Jesus

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 2nd October 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
15:49 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
17:32 - United Reformed Church 50th anniversary memorabilia 19:49 - Call to worship With the whole Christian Church, the United Reformed Church believes in one God, Father, Son and Holy Spirit. Glory to God in highest heaven: peace to all people on earth.
20:10 - Hymn - R&S 29 Father we love you
21:33 - The life of faith to which we are called is the Spirit’s gift continually received through the Word, the Sacraments and our Christian life together: Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
22:08 - Opening Prayers
23:58 - 29:00 - Introduction for all ages – joined together I would have loved to give each of you a piece of this 50th anniversary jigsaw but there is nothing more annoying than a missing piece What kind of piece would you be? Corner, curly, straight? I was sent a single piece this week, sent to URC ministers Every time you reach 35 years in the URC ministry, you receive a symbolic piece to show how you are part of the one church family Coming together as one family, united in peace, joining pieces together. When we take the small piece of bread, it reminds us we are all a part of the one body of Christ, building to make one huge picture together As reminders we have cards showing Faith, Hope, and Love with 4 questions for each day How have I acted with love today? How have I lived the life of Jesus today? How have I lived my faith today? How have I walked with hope today?
29:23 - 29:52 - Reading: Psalm 133 (Good News) 133 How wonderful it is, how pleasant, for God's people to live together in harmony! 2 It is like the precious anointing oil running down from Aaron's head and beard, down to the collar of his robes. 3 It is like the dew on Mount Hermon, falling on the hills of Zion. That is where the Lord has promised his blessing— life that never ends.
30:42 - 31:30 - Trinity Vision: Small Groups
31:54 - 34:12 - Trinity Vision: Midweek Café
34:20 - Songs R&S 565 Jesus stand among us TP 4 All heaven declares
40:33 - Introducing the readings The highest authority for what we believe and do is God’s Word in the Bible alive for his people today through the help of the Spirit. Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
41:13 - 42:07 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 12. 1 – 5, 12 – 13, 31 (NIVUK) 42:33 - Reaction to the reading
43:37 - Held together in the Body of Christ through the freedom of the Spirit, we rejoice in the diversity of the Spirit’s gifts and uphold the rights of personal conviction. For the sake of faith and fellowship it shall be for the church to decide where differences of conviction hurt our unity and peace. Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
42:10 - A Prayer of the unity and peace in the church family
45:35 - 47:30 - Reading: 1 Corinthians 13. 1 – 13 (NIVUK)
48:28 - Hymn - R&S 354 Come, Living God, when least expected
51:53 - 01:01:43 - Short Talk: ‘Faith, hope and love NOW’ Are you among the ardent youth or the mellow age? Most of us rather mellow Thinking of our anniversary, I tried to remember what it was like being 50 I remember being 40 more than 50 I was given an axe for my 50th birthday - in a pub! What is it like being 50 In the history of the Church, 50 is nothing really, even less in the history of humanity, it's just a blink of an eye Faith, Hope, Love since 1972 for the URC Paul's 1st letter to the Corinthians Ch 13. A difficult letter he was writing Replace the word "love" with "Jesus" to understand more Paul longs for people to reflect that love in their lives We believe in a loving God, not a condemning God We have many convictions, expressed in different ways yet we hold that common faith in a loving God and Jesus There are three things that last forever - faith, hope, and love and the greatest of these is love - hold on to that
01:01:49 - We affirm our intention to go on praying and working, with all our fellow Christians, for the visible unity of the Church in the way Christ chooses, so that people and nations may be led to love and serve God and praise him more and more, for ever. Glory to God in highest heaven; peace to all people on earth.
01:02:47 - 01:04:50 - Prayers for the church and the world
01:04:55 - Hymn - R&S 469 As we are gathered Jesus is here
01:07:33 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Jesus Christ
01:07:33 - A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
01:10:52 - 01:17:23 - Distribution of Communion and Closing Prayer
01:17:24 - Hymn - R&S 603 Lord for the years
01:21:18 - 01:21:50 - Blessing
01:22:18 - 1:26:31 - Music and notices after the service
#communion #urc #vision #corinthians #jigsaw #FaithHopeLove #corner

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 18th September Harvest 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
15:07 - Welcome, introduction and call to worship
17:22 - Call to worship
17:52 - Hymn - Praise and thanksgiving (R&S 48)
20:16 - Opening Prayer of thanksgiving
22:17 - 28:04 - Introduction: ‘harvest links’ The harvest display connects us with people across the country and across the world Sunflower oil and sunflowers to creation and Ukraine An ear of wheat - gleaning the leftovers after harvest from the field behind Cores End church - farmers everywhere A coin - connecting to the Queen, thinking of the late Queen Elizabeth II and her family An envelope - connecting us with the people in Africa experiencing a vicious drought, supported by Christian Aid A can - connecting to One Can, our local foodbank supporting people in need
28:05 - 40:18 - One Can Update
40:25 - 42:21 - Reading: Psalm 65. 1, 5-13 (CEV)
42:51 - Song - Our God is a great big God
44:57 - Short Christian Aid Film: the Crisis in East Africa
47:56 - Prayer for East Africa Loving and compassionate God, When Famine stalks the land, nothing grows. Plants cannot, people cannot, ideas and dreams cannot everything withers and dies. It is a violent aberration of your will for the world and it is multiplied now by conflict, climate change and covid. God of the flourishing field, there is enough to feed us all. Call us to that sacred sharing, neighbour to global neighbour, your gifts of food, water, a chance to live the life so delicately crafted by your divine spirit. We will not turn away but turn towards each other with generosity and a justice-driven compassion that searches for solutions. Famine stalks the land, so may our outrage grow, may our determination steel itself, may our solidarity spur us into action. God of the flourishing field, help us feed each other. Amen.
50:26 - Song - Come all you people, come and praise your maker (video) Uyai mose, tinamate mwari. (x3) Uyai mose zvino.
Activity for children at back of church
52:45 - 54:05 - Reading: Luke 12 8.1 – 9 13 Someone in the crowd said to him, ‘Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me.’ 14 Jesus replied, ‘Man, who appointed me a judge or an arbiter between you?’ 15 Then he said to them, ‘Watch out! Be on your guard against all kinds of greed; life does not consist in an abundance of possessions.’ 16 And he told them this parable: ‘The ground of a certain rich man yielded an abundant harvest. 17 He thought to himself, “What shall I do? I have no place to store my crops.” 18 ‘Then he said, “This is what I’ll do. I will tear down my barns and build bigger ones, and there I will store my surplus grain. 19 And I’ll say to myself, ‘You have plenty of grain laid up for many years. Take life easy; eat, drink and be merry.’” 20 ‘But God said to him, “You fool! This very night your life will be demanded from you. Then who will get what you have prepared for yourself?” 21 ‘This is how it will be with whoever stores up things for themselves but is not rich towards God.’
54:42 - Song - Give thanks with a grateful heart (MP 170)
57:42 - 01:06:30 - Short Talk We live connected lives Our display connects us with many people - rich and poor, black and white, friends and enemies Many situations linked to us, we can not live in a vacuum The rich man in the parable tries this, no concern for his workers, just what to do with all his wealth - go for growth, growth, growth It could be a parable of the western world Jesus said to be on guard for all kinds of greed Life does not consist of an abundance of possessions Reflecting on the life of our Queen, we could say she was one of the top 0.1% in terms of wealth but looking at her lifetime of service, what she has done is incredible. "Each day is a new beginning, I know that the only way to live my life is to try to do what is right" Jesus said - whoever stores up things for themselves but is not rich towards God Let's speak to God today, come clean, and be challenged to live our lives better putting our trust in Our loving Saviour
01:06:32 - Hymn - God whose farm is all creation (R&S 612)
Offering of our gifts (symbolic gifts)
01:08:22 - Prayers of intercession for the world Lord of all the harvest Hear our prayer.
01:14:11 - The Lord’s Prayer
01:15:18 - Hymn - Fill your hearts with joy (MP 147)
01:18:39 - 01:19:04 - Blessing
01:19:29 - 01:22:35 - Music and notices after the service
#onecan #foodbank #queenelizabeth #tribute #harvest #creation #paddington #ukraine

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - 11th September 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Music before the service
00:12:40 Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
16:48 - Call to worship:
18:18 - Hymn - Our God our help in ages past R&S 705
21:51 - Opening Prayer
24:07 - The Lord’s Prayer
25:20 - 27:17 - Reading: Luke 15 vv 1-10 read by Norma Now the tax collectors and sinners were all gathering round to hear Jesus. 2 But the Pharisees and the teachers of the law muttered, ‘This man welcomes sinners, and eats with them.’ 3 Then Jesus told them this parable: 4 ‘Suppose one of you has a hundred sheep and loses one of them. Doesn’t he leave the ninety-nine in the open country and go after the lost sheep until he finds it? 5 And when he finds it, he joyfully puts it on his shoulders 6 and goes home. Then he calls his friends and neighbours together and says, “Rejoice with me; I have found my lost sheep.” 7 I tell you that in the same way there will be more rejoicing in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous people who do not need to repent. The parable of the lost coin 8 ‘Or suppose a woman has ten silver coins[a] and loses one. Doesn’t she light a lamp, sweep the house and search carefully until she finds it? 9 And when she finds it, she calls her friends and neighbours together and says, “Rejoice with me; I have found my lost coin.” 10 In the same way, I tell you, there is rejoicing in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who repents.’
27:30 - 30:52 - Talk for All ages I remember the chaplain coming to my last place of work Misunderstanding the chaplain referring to us as a flock of sheep Driving home from Wales one night and a sheep ran out into the side of the road. God loves all of us and doesn't want any one of us to be lost Lots of things make us wander off from God Everyday life, tragedies etc. We can help by doing something that sheep do a lot - bleat, which for us translates to praying Remember the God forgives when we return to him and ask for forgiveness
30:54 - Hymn: Brother sister let me serve you R&S 474
34:28 - 36:07 - Reading: 1 Timothy 1 vv 12-17 read by Alan 2 I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who has given me strength, that he considered me trustworthy, appointing me to his service. 13 Even though I was once a blasphemer and a persecutor and a violent man, I was shown mercy because I acted in ignorance and unbelief. 14 The grace of our Lord was poured out on me abundantly, along with the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus. 15 Here is a trustworthy saying that deserves full acceptance: Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners – of whom I am the worst. 16 But for that very reason I was shown mercy so that in me, the worst of sinners, Christ Jesus might display his immense patience as an example for those who would believe in him and receive eternal life. 17 Now to the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only God, be honour and glory for ever and ever. Amen.
36:17 - Hymn: The King of love my shepherd is R&S 552
39:46 - 49:32 - Sermon followed by time of quite reflection We heard two parables today, the lost sheep and the lost coin Different but vividly illustrating the truth of John 3:16 - God so loved the world that he gave his only Son Both follow the same pattern: 1. Something is lost 2. There is a search for the thing that is lost 3. There is great joy when the thing that is lost is found How the things are lost are not important to the parables The items are regarded as precious by their owner, just as we are regarded by God Jesus is the shepherd not content to be happy with the 99, he will go out and look for the missing one God so loved us that whilst we were still sinners, he gave His Son We need a daily awareness of the gospel in our lives to keep us humble before our Saviour Do we look down on the sinners around us or do we seek the sinners as the lost needing to be found?
51:18 - Hymn: Eternal Father of the ceaseless round R&S 623
56:08 - Prayers of Intercession
01:00:35 - Hymn: God is love let heaven adore Him R&S 95
01:04:37 - 01:05:06 - Blessing
01:05:28 - 01:10:12 - Music and notices after the service
#queenelizabeth #photostory #worship #parables
